abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Education
            Project for Guinea was satisfactory. The project achieved
            most of its objectives, sustainability is likely with
            adequate operating budgets, and the performance of both the
            Bank and Borrower was satisfactory. Two main lessons can be
            learned from this project. First, projects should be
            designed to fit local situations. Also, if there is no sense
            of "ownership" at the local level, there can
            really be no commitment and project objectives cannot be
            sustained. Second, IDA does not appear to have assured that
            effective mechanisms to monitor project activities and
            safeguard against the risks inherent in the complexity and
            diversity of project objectives were put in place. This
            situation emphasizes the problem of matching the resources
            needed for adequate implementation to the needs of the
            project, including staffing continuity and adequate
            specialization. This can be resolved by either the IDA
            providing adequate resources or assuring that borrowers
            engage sufficient specialist advice within the project.
